Otherwise, the game will end immediately with a three-point margin.  3:  Each team, as if on its own, may play one more half, or, if this is not feasible, may begin each quarter on a defensive strategy. (As an example, two of their players may play the whole half and then the other half. Both halves of the game would be played on offense or defense until someone scores enough points for the win or tie.)  4:  Both halves of each game may be played on offense or on defense throughout the game, but not for more than three minutes or so, even if neither team plays the rest of the game, so that each team feels the win is earned.
Output: A

Identify Animals on the South Side of Chicago

Animals commonly caught on the South Side of Chicagoland include: dogs, cats and rabbits.

The number of animals caught on the South Side per year depends on the number of available animals on the South Side. The year-round population on the South Side is approximately 90% residential, 10% light industry, and 10% light industry.

The animals commonly caught on the South side are mainly in the area surrounding the Loop and University.

The animals most commonly caught in the Loop are dogs and cats. In contrast, the most commonly caught animals on the South side are rabbits.

The animals typically caught on the South side of the zoo on the north side are rabbits and cats. This is because that side of the zoo has a smaller, smaller and more manageable enclosure. Dogs are usually caught on the south side.

The animals caught on the South side by the zoo are much heavier, bulkier animals. The larger the animal, the harder it is to catch on the South side.

The South Side is more densely populated near downtown. The animals caught on the Southside typically come from the suburbs of the city. Some of the most concentrated pockets of animals in the Southside are in the Logan and East Town sections.

The animals, mostly cats, that are most commonly caught in the South Side are often caught at zoos around the area.

Explanation:  When someone dies, a wake is the traditional ceremony before a funeral.  A wake is a gathering of family and friends where many are invited, usually on a regular basis.  The purpose of the wake is to honor the life and memory of the dead, perhaps by giving away food, clothing, or money.

Input: What happens to a married couple when one spouse dies? Does the other spouse live at the couple’s home? If so, what happens to the home?
Output: Yes, the husband goes with his wife to live at the other wife’s home, but they are not married in their current location.  In this case, the home is considered shared and owned jointly.
Explanation
1. The wife is still married to the original wife; she is still alive.  Therefore the house is still owned by one wife and used as two separate homes.  When someone dies, that residence still exists as two separate homes and can continue to be lived in in-house without a divorce.  A couple might be together at one of the homes and then married at another after a divorce.

input: A farmer named Hester Prynne planted strawberries at the farm when they had not rained in ten years.  The strawberries were growing great so she planted more strawberries.  A few years later she planted another plant and the plants became bigger.  This made it even more impossible to plant strawberries and she tried to plant nothing but strawberries for 10 years but after ten years she was getting tired of growing strawberries and she began planting nothing but strawberries.  She decided to plant tomatoes, which grew beautifully.  Then she planted some cabbages so that she could eat vegetables with her meals.  Three years later she planted beans and one year ago she planted lettuce, and next year she planted radishes, peas, and zucchini.  When she saw all of these plants growing she said to herself, “this is where God has planted me.”  She became so happy that she never thought twice about growing food again.  But one day after she finished working on a strawberry patch she went to collect her tomatoes and she saw a tomato bush that had been harvested only two weeks ago.  Her heart sank.  When she came back to the strawberry patch she discovered some of her strawberries had grown into beautiful bush of strawberries.  She became so depressed and went into the house and cried for several hours until she thought about how beautiful the bush of strawberries looked.  She decided to harvest all of her harvest on her birthday and celebrate.  So she went out on her farm to harvest her strawberries and began eating some of the strawberries she had harvested and she was so happy that she looked at her strawberry bush and realized that her happiness came from the food that she created instead of from the harvest she gathered herself.  The happiness came from the food she created instead of from what God gave her.
The word for happy is: joy.(2)

In-house training
The Army also sponsors two-week in-house training for troops before deploying to war.  A typical two-week training course is split into five sections, taught in small groups, each containing 200 or 300 soldiers.  The training is intensive to help soldiers gain important technical knowledge so they can perform at their best. This process is called technical training and may consist of individual workshops or a few classroom exercises.  The entire course can last more than a month.  During the 2 weeks in-house training the soldier undergoes the course's requirements for military intelligence, operations and communications.  Following the course, the soldiers are moved to a permanent camp where they receive additional training from military instructors.
Training in-house often takes place at Fort Leavenworth in Kansas. Other Army regiments that conduct such training include 1st Cavalry Division and 1st Infantry Division.  More in-house training activities are performed at Joint Base Lewis-McChord in Washington.  Each year the Army holds an exercise in which soldiers learn how to perform emergency preparedness.

In-house Training Exercise
An annual exercise is the Army's largest training event. Known as Exercise Anaconda, it includes 40,000 troops from all four branches of the military on 30,000 acres (12,000 square miles) of former Rocky Mountain mining camp land in Glacier National Park.  The exercise has been held four times since 1985, and has been the Army's largest training exercise since 1985. Exercise Anaconda consists of six separate phases, each requiring approximately one-thousand of a soldier's time. The exercise usually lasts for about three weeks, and consists of multiple phases to simulate multiple combat operations. Most of the exercises in exercise Anaconda are simulated combat operations, but occasionally live soldiers participate as well.
Training exercises at Fort Leavenworth take place during three separate periods

The coach leaves immediately and gives his other three players the prize of the game.  When they all get home, the boys tell the coach he's an idiot.  The coach gets even angrier, thinking that it only took 5 questions to find him but 3 on his team to find the boy.  One more time, he calls every boy he knows to see if they heard the interview and was curious to hear what the boy really likes to do.  He goes to get a list of names from everyone he knows.  He calls back and the entire team is there together.  They agree it's the most important question they've ever heard.  The coach says, "We found him.  He's a boy.  I can hardly wait for you to see him."  The team gathers and comes in.  Now for the twist:  the coach calls each boy a name as he comes through the door.  He is shocked and disgusted that none of his team heard the question, and the other players can't hide their surprise because they're in the same room with him.  When the boys get out of the room, everyone laughs.  When he gets back to this house, the boy tells the coach, he only likes to play on the street and he has never heard the coach say that kind of thing about any of his teammates. Output: A

[C]: But so hath been the case unto us all from this time (till) these forty moons

[D]: But I think it was more at the beginning, when it was in the ground. I am certain that there was more

[E]: And yet there would be nothing of it - even if it had never been in the ground - if it never had been sown or raised, and had been in the air all this time.

The teacher's answers:

-- A does not apply because he did not know whether it was the penny or a full dollar. He just had to do it as he had his eye on it. His pupil already knows the answer.

-- B does not work. The answer was "when they are in air all the time", as the word is used in the verse.

-- C does not work for the same reason.

-- D does not apply because the time for this event was not after the time he has studied it. So we would need to find the event before "when they were in air all the time."

The problem:
1. The student's answers:
A.Dissipate or spread out in the air- dispersed
B.Fled - flew
C.Decayed - disintegrated
D.Fell apart- fell apart
E.Floated - floated

2. The teacher's answers:
A:Fled
B:Decayed
C:Disappeared
D:Won
E:Floated

3. The student's answers are the same, in that they are all correct, but they are correct in reverse order. If we rearrange the answers into a sequence, the correct answer can be found in the following:

1.Dissipate: - scattered, dispersed
2.Floated: - raised, floating
3.Decayed: - disintegrated
4.Fled: - flown
5.Won: - won, lost
6.Decayed: - deteriorated

C

Commentary:

(This is a discussion on the passage. I think it is a good question)

Answer : The more we read science-fiction, the closer it seems to becoming the reality. The more often a film is shown, the more we realize how real it is. The more the story moves closer to fact, the greater our fear becomes. (There is one sentence on page 60, the answer should be right in front of it!)

Comments :

The more we read science- fiction, the closer it seems it would become reality as well. The more often a movie is shown, the greater our fear seems to increase. The more often the story moves closer to reality, the more we start to notice its similarities. In the story the main characters do not die in an instant. We realize that the main protagonists do live through many events in their lifes.

The answer is D. The main characters in the story do not die in an in a instant. They do not have a quick death, either when the story is still in the beginning or when the story reaches its climax. When they start to die, the reader knows it is their will that prevents it. They do not just die, but they are pulled into a state with a great death. That is why they are so sad when they realise that their character will not die. A normal death is much more painful and shocking than a sudden death. We can all imagine a scene where the main character is about to die. That is not the same thing.

You may have noticed that there is no question mark in the answer. It is a very common question in exams, and it is almost always answered in a negative way. To be fair the answer is D; after all the main characters do not suffer in a quick death like in any other story.

Comments :
To be fair, it is a very common question. I am guessing the professor gives it to many students. If the students were to write other answers, the answers would probably have a question mark in the answer box. Students don't answer questions with negative comments. So, the choice is clear.

The architect observes on the same roof, and he finds a fourth house that needs repairing.  The engineer stops the work and reports back to the architect, "We must fix the house that the builder has identified as needing the most roof repair."  The architect agrees with the engineer and continues with the work on the 3 houses without any delays.  In the final house, the roof leaks in such a way that it can no longer be fixed.  The architect asks the engineer what he saw there.  "A leak," replied the engineer.  "I never saw such a leak!" exclaimed the architect.  "I see the roof of a house.  Who's to say that the house that the builder identified as needing the most repair has had the leak fixed?"  The engineer points to a second house.  The architect asks, "Where and to whom did he see the leak from the first house to the second?"  The engineer replies:  He saw the roof of the second house, and he told them who it was.  "I saw the leak on a house that the builder identified," replied the architect.  "In two different houses I did, and I never saw such leaks."  The engineer then said, "What did the house that the builder indicated he wanted repaired the most have?"  The architect replied:  It had been repaired the least.  "Then I agree with you.  In all three houses that I inspected and reported the leak to the builder, I never saw that house repaired.  To you I am foolhardy, dear fellow."
